newsitem.title: UK: UK CBI opposes minimum wage, social chapter.
newsitem.headline: UK CBI opposes minimum wage, social chapter.

text.p: The Confederation of British Industry said on Monday it remained concerned about a number of opposition Labour Party policies including a minimum wage, the European Social Chapter, and windfall taxes on Britain's privatised utilities.
But CBI director-general Adair Turner told BBC television that he welcomed the narrowing of the gap in policies between Labour and the ruling Conservative Party.
"There has been a significant narrowing of the gap and that is welcome," Turner said. "That doesn't mean we agree with everything they are saying."
He said a windfall tax on privatised utilities was "a bad principle of public finance", even if it was believed they were undersold at their flotation in the first place.
Turner said the CBI did not support signing up to the EU's Social Chapter, which the Labour Party has said it will do.
"We support the opt out from the Social Chapter...because of what it may lead to," he said.

"On the other hand we are very keen to make sure that the Labour Party firms up on a commitment that it has given that it wouldn't increase the scope of qualified majority voting under the Social Chapter."
He said he backed Labour Party commitments to education and training but said the minimum wage, if set at 4.26 stg, could have a "significant impact on jobs."
Earlier this month, the Trades Union Congress called for a minimum wage of 4.26 per hour, but Labour's front bench has declined to make any specific comment on a possible level.
